Shogun: Total War isn’t just a game, it’s a time machine that transported me back to feudal Japan, igniting a love for strategy games and Japanese culture that still burns brightly. 
Playing this gem back in the day was a revelation, and revisiting it now is like opening a treasure chest of nostalgia!
Set in the tumultuous Sengoku Jidai period, Shogun: Total War masterfully captures the drama, strategy, and brutality of clan warfare.
Taking control of one of the great clans, you must navigate the complex web of diplomacy, economics, and battlefield tactics to unite Japan under your banner. 
The game’s campaign map, with its simple yet effective visuals, always felt like a living, breathing world, a sandbox where history was mine to rewrite.
The tactical battles are where Shogun truly shines. 
Seeing thousands of samurai, archers, and cavalry clash on beautifully rendered battlefields was nothing short of awe-inspiring at the time. 
Even today, the game’s attention to historical accuracy and detail remains impressive! 
The ability to carefully position your units, plan ambushes, and use the terrain to your advantage made every skirmish feel like a thrilling puzzle.
What elevated the experience for me was how steeped the game was in Japanese culture. 
From the elegant art style and authentic sound effects to the deeply strategic gameplay that mirrored the discipline of samurai warfare, Shogun immersed me in the world of feudal Japan like no other game could. 
The poetic haikus accompanying end-of-turn summaries were a particularly lovely touch, adding atmosphere and gravitas to your decisions.
Of course, by today’s standards, some mechanics feel dated, and the AI wasn’t always the sharpest tactician. 
But these minor flaws are easily forgiven when considering the innovation and ambition Shogun brought to gaming in its time. 
For anyone who loves strategy games or has a deep appreciation for Japanese history, Shogun: Total War is a classic worth cherishing. 
For me, it’s more than a game, it’s a nostalgic journey to a time when I first discovered the thrill of commanding samurai armies and conquering Japan, one province at a time...

183648063.review:
My first 3D strategy game, played all the way in 2000. And it has aged beautifully. If at the time I looked at those rolling hills and rain storms and thought "wow so realistic" now I can admire and say "wow so minimalist". 

I still find this to be the most immersive Total War experience. The only game where even the strategic map makes you feel like a general, moving pieces around. The "realism" of later Total War games ruined it.  Everything, from the music to the AI to the graphics, was decades ahead of its time, and still a joy today.

PS If you're playing on the Steam Deck, just use Proton Experimental and it works fine.
